answerText: Turner syndrome[10] This second most common cause of Turner syndrome occurs when some cells lose their X chromosome during the early stages of embryonic development. In this condition, cells within a person have a different genetic makeup.
heading: ACF Regionals |2013 | Rutgers-NB + St. Johns A + Haverford | 7 | Science | Biology | College
subject: Science
question: Question: Clinical features of this syndrome include a short neck with webbed appearance, multiple pigmented nevi, and low-set ears. For 10 points each: [10] Name this genetic condition in which females only a single X chromosome.
